original_title: Sri Lanka to study Infobip centralized SMS firewall proposal
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT- Sri Lanka’s Cabinet of ministers have granted approval to evaluate a short message service firewall by a company called Infobip to set up a centralised anti-phishing system.
“It has been observed that the excessive use of a short message system has led to fraud, spam and illegal activities,” a government statement said.

“Therefore, it has been recognized of the requirement of a centralized short message system network security appliance firewall (SMS Firewall) to regularize short message exchange in order to confront such challenges.”
The system will cover SMS and MMS messaging, the statement said.
Infobip, which the post-cabinet statement said was a UK-based firm, had submitted a proposal to set up an “international A2P (application to person) short message services centre”.

President Ranil Wickremesinghe has proposed appointing a committee with representatives from the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Technology and the Sri Lanka Telecom Regulatory Commission to evaluate the proposal.

In addition to spamming, “smishing” (which is similar to phishing, which occurs via email) is a form of cyberattacks that uses text messages, or SMS (Short Message Service), to trick people into disclosing personal information, opening dangerous links, or downloading malicious files on their devices.
It was not clear whether telecom operators would be consulted. (Colombo/Jan04/2023)
